appropriations: Testimony from Hina Mauka supports the Tobacco coalition’s proposed amendment to add a $0.01 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) increase to the bill such that the cigarette tax increases from 16 cents to 19 cents. [8] Other testimony respectfully requests consideration of at least a $0.05 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) per cigarette ($1.00 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) per pack) increase instead of the $0.02 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) per cigarette ($0.40 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) per pack) increase currently proposed. [8]
agency_impact: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) requests that the effective date be amended to January 1, 2026 to provide sufficient time for DOTAX to update stamps and implement the system and form changes necessary for the proposed increase. [8] [8]
economic_impact: The annual estimated health care costs directly caused by smoking in Hawaii is $611 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt). [8] Smoking-caused government expenditures result in a tax burden of $955.00 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) per household and $1.1 billion (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) in lost productivity in Hawaii. [8] Testimony in opposition argues that the bill will drive more sales into the untaxed and unregulated black market, harming law-abiding retailers and undermining the very tax base it aims to strengthen. [8]
policy_impact: The Department of the Attorney General asks that the Committee also consider House Bill No. 1085, which similarly raises the cigarette tax rate but aims to move away from relying on cigarette taxes and expands the tax revenue base to include all revenue collected under chapter 245, HRS, including the new tax revenue collected from e-cigarettes and e-liquids. [8] [8] Your Committee on Finance is in accord with the intent and purpose of H.B. No. 441, H.D. 2, and recommends that it pass Third Reading. [9]
revenue_sources: The attached chart from the Department of the Attorney General demonstrates FY24 revenues including $8,606,752 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) for the Hawaii Cancer Research Special Fund and $5,379,220 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) for the Emergency Medical Services Special Fund. [8] The Community Health Centers Special Fund also received $5,379,220 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt), while ESDs & e-liquids and all other tobacco products generated $12,083,794 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt). [8] Total Cigarette Revenue for FY24 was $70,092,426 (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt). [8]
six_year_fiscal_implications: Testimony from the Taxpayers Protection Alliance notes that while previous tax hikes (2006–2011) temporarily boosted revenue, the gains were not sustained, with collections declining annually since 2012. [8] The Aloha State collected $135.6 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) in cigarette excise taxes in 2011, which was a 63.2 percent increase from 2005’s $83.1 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt). [8] However, cigarette tax revenue declined each year since 2012, and in 2023, Hawaii collected $76.8 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) in cigarette excise taxes, which was a 43.4 percent decrease from 2011’s increases. [8] Testimony from an individual provided alternative 5-year healthcare cost savings projections, including from fewer smoking-caused heart attacks and strokes at -$250,000 and 5-year Medicaid program savings for the state at -$1.06 million. [8] This testimony projects long-term health care cost savings from adult and youth smoking declines at $41.22 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt). [8]
operating_revenue_impact: Testimony from the Taxpayers Protection Alliance provides historical data showing that a series of tax increases from 2006 to 2011 led to several years of increased cigarette tax revenue. [8] Revenue increased from 2005's $83.1 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) to $135.6 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) in 2011, but these increases were not experienced in the long term. [8] Cigarette tax revenue has been declining each year since 2012, with 2023 collections of $76.8 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) representing a $58.8 million (HB441_HD2_TESTIMONY_FIN_02-21-25_.PDF.txt) decrease from the 2011 peak. [8]
fiscal_implications_after_6_years: Testimony from the Tax Foundation states that excise taxes, particularly those applied to a shrinking tax base, make a poor policy solution to a shortfall. [8] Fiscal reliance on funds from a sin tax is inadvisable, perhaps outright dangerous. [8] [8] Testimony from the Taxpayers Protection Alliance notes that policymakers should refrain from relying on revenue generated by state cigarette excise taxes, as cigarette tax revenue has declined due to declines in smoking rates. [8]
